text:
to echo <@UJG9WTEKG> and <@UJDPMTREY>, I think the nuts-and-bolts of on-page SEO is... pretty easy to learn, and something that any decent writer could internalise quickly

the harder intersection between content/SEO is all the supporting infrastructure:

• which search terms reflect the right intent and audience in the first place?
• how should content be structured as a cohesive whole, and not just a bunch of ad-hoc standalone articles?
• what's the right dynamic between site pages and content?
• how should new content be differentiated from the existing search results?
• etc.
...all of which make a lot of sense for a dedicated writer and dedicate SEO to collaborate on together. so yeah, I definitely think there's a market for "just" being a great writer and working with people that are "just" great SEOs :)

elements.text: to echo

which search terms reflect the right intent and audience in the first place?
how should content be structured as a cohesive whole, and not just a bunch of ad-hoc standalone articles?
what's the right dynamic between site pages and content?
how should new content be differentiated from the existing search results?
etc.

...all of which make a lot of sense for a dedicated writer and dedicate SEO to collaborate on together. so yeah, I definitely think there's a market for "just" being a great writer and working with people that are "just" great SEOs :)

text: Is there a way around having a “thank you” page listed as an orphan page? As I understand it, it’s listed as such b/c there are no internal links to it, which—it seems—there shouldn’t be. Unless I’m wrong?

elements.text: Is there a way around having a “thank you” page listed as an orphan page? As I understand it, it’s listed as such b/c there are no internal links to it, which—it seems—there shouldn’t be. Unless I’m wrong?

text: ty!

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text: ty!

text: What's wrong with it being orphaned?

elements.text: What's wrong with it being orphaned?

text: It was my understanding that an orphaned page is bad for SEO. Should I not worry about it in this case?

elements.text: It was my understanding that an orphaned page is bad for SEO. Should I not worry about it in this case?

text:
It is if you're trying to rank a page, but not for something like a "thank you" page, which you should have set to "noindex" anyhow. (otherwise, it might show up in search results for, say, branded queries, and your goal tracking in google analytics may be calculated based on the number of users/sessions to that page; thus, an indexed "thank you" page can squirrel your conversion data.)

for pages you _do_ want to rank, the challenge is that "orphaned" pages can be (1) hard for search engines to discover and (2) don't get any "link equity" from internal links pointing to the page from other pages on your site. the search engine assumption is that an orphaned page probably isn't that important and, therefore, doesn't deserve to be ranked highly. there are exceptions to the rule, of course.

elements.text:

text: Dream = Get a customer/SME to sit down with a writer who knows how to pull both a narrative and educational piece out of a conversation.

elements.text: Dream = Get a customer/SME to sit down with a writer who knows how to pull both a narrative and educational piece out of a conversation.

text:
<@UJ99RGF7T> Totally agree. I’ve been lucky to work with some great writers that know how to hit that balance.

I think it should be said that another way to do this is to ghostwrite on behalf of the SME/customer using the same interview process. Same thing: narrative about the steps someone took to accomplish something great. Just told in the first person.

I didn’t share examples of that because… well…. it’s ghostwriting. :)
